[@trav](@Gs0Rz7yEabDd1GyrnjZ1acPrcHL+rx8irnLl4ys/sU4=.ed25519) 

Thanks! I actually *just* saw some of your Sim City 2000 videos on Vimeo after watching your dweb camp video. I never played it but I like base building games so I'd imagine it might be cool? I'm super inspired by [mapgen4](https://www.redblobgames.com/maps/mapgen4/) too, all the good map generators are use fancy gradient noise for elevation but mine just goes to each tile and does a sequence of steps:

- flip a weighted coin to determine whether it should be land -- the coin *heavily* favors water, so there are only a few random islands around the map
- if the tile is water near land, flip a weighted coin to determine whether it should become land as well -- this lets islands expand and sprawl and connect to each other
- if the tile is a land tile with 3 water neighbors, delete it -- this minimizes thin sprawling peninsulas
- if the tile is a water tile and land is > 2 tiles away, mark it as ocean
- if the tile is land and surrounded by land, flip a coin to determine whether it should become a mountain -- this coin is weighted toward *not* becoming a mountain unless there are other mountains nearby, which is how it makes small mountain ranges
- if the tile is a mountain tile with too few mountain neighbors or too many mountain neighbors, delete it (similar to the peninsula deletion)
- if the tile is a land tile with no other settlements nearby, flip a weighted coin to determine if it becomes a settlement
- if the tile is a land tile surrounded by land tiles, flip a weighted coin to determine if it becomes a forest -- forests are more likely to spawn near other forests *and* near mountains

The probabilities were a pain in the ass to tune because I tried to get them to work regardless of the board size, so most of them are like `1 / squareRoot(boardWidth)` or something silly.
